revised_title: Experimental Demonstration of the Energetic Cost of Parasitism in Free-Ranging Hosts
tldr: The study demonstrates that feather-feeding lice on feral rock doves can reduce host condition through the accumulation of subtle energetic costs over time. The lice reduced feather mass, leading to increased thermal conductance and metabolic rate, as well as a steady reduction in host body mass over the course of the nine-month study. This shows that even 'benign' parasites can have indirect effects on host fitness.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Ecology and Evolution
